author: Clare Hutchison, JIM ARMITAGE
title: Revealed: Waitrose reveals job cuts in management shake-up
text:
Wednesday 8 February 2017 16:47 GMT Click to followThe Evening Standard Axe to jobs: Waitrose is consulting with staff about redundancies Stefan Wermuth/Reuters 
Waitrose is set to axe almost 200 jobs and close a number of shops as part of a shake-up of its store network, the Evening Standard can reveal. 
The upmarket grocer confirmed 180 jobs are at risk as part of plans to simplify the management structure at its 350 stores. 
AWaitrose spokesman said: “We are proposing that, over the next three years, our department managers will transition to the new role of deputy branch manager. We currently have 486 department managers (UK wide) and gradually between now and 2020 we expect this number to reduce by around 180.” 
It added that the reduction would be through natural turnover, retirements and voluntary redundancies. 
The firm also today proposed the closure of five stores across the country, including in Staines, Hertford and Palmers Green. 
Waitrose pointed out however that it is investing in new branches and its existing estate, with new jobs being created. 
The moves come after parent company the John Lewis Partnership warned last month of a “challenging market outlook” due to the pound’s post-Referendum plunge. 
Sterling’s weakness will push up prices of goods from abroad, leaving retailers and shoppers facing higher prices. 
Conditions for supermarkets are already tough: competition from discounters Aldi and Lidl has forced the major grocers like Tesco and Sainsbury’s to slash prices. 
Meanwhile Aldi and Lidl have expanded premium ranges to lure more middle class customers away from Waitrose and M&S. 
Sales at Waitrose stores open for more than a year fell 1% in its first half, while operating profit dropped 10.5% to £121.3 million. 
It fared better at Christmas, with same-store sales rising 2.8%, but bosses said group trading profit remains “under pressure” due to “greater changes” in the retail sector. 
Staff were told to expect “significantly lower” bonuses for this year. More about:
